description: From Middle English quarere, from Medieval Latin quarreria (1266), literally a “place where stones are squared”, from Old French quarrière (compare modern French carrière), from Vulgar Latin *quadraria, from Latin quadrō (“I square”), itself from quadra (“a square”), from quattuor (“four”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *kʷetwóres (“four”).

entries.meaning: (mining) A site for mining stone, limestone, or slate.
examples: Michelangelo personally quarried marble from the world-famous quarry at Carrara.

verbs.description: quarry (third-person singular simple present quarries, present participle quarrying, simple past and past participle quarried)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To obtain (or mine) stone by extraction from a quarry.
(figuratively, transitive) To extract or slowly obtain by long, tedious searching.
examples: They quarried out new, interesting facts about ancient Egypt from old papyri.

description: From Middle English quyrrey, querre, curee, quirre, from Anglo-Norman quirreie, from Old French cuiriee (“entrails of deer placed on the hide and given to dogs of the chase as a reward”) (influenced by cuir (“skin (of an animal)”), from Latin corium (“a hide”)), from coree (“entrails, viscera”), from Vulgar Latin corata (“entrails”), from Latin cor (“heart”).

entries.meaning: (uncountable, obsolete) A part of the entrails of a hunted animal, given to the hounds as a reward.
(uncountable) An animal, often a bird or mammal, which is hunted.
(countable) An object of search or pursuit.

verbs.description: quarry (third-person singular simple present quarries, present participle quarrying, simple past and past participle quarried)

entries.meaning: To secure prey; to prey, as a vulture or harpy.

description: Alteration of quarrel (“diamond-shaped piece of coloured glass forming part of a stained glass window; square tile”).

entries.meaning: A diamond-shaped tile or pane, often of glass or stone.
